docs.abstract: “We don’t have the brains to answer the question of what it was that rock ’n’ roll tried to start and has failed to finish.”
docs.snippet: “We don’t have the brains to answer the question of what it was that rock ’n’ roll tried to start and has failed to finish.”
docs.lead_paragraph: “We don’t have the brains to answer the question of what it was that rock ’n’ roll tried to start and has failed to finish.”

headline.main: The Who’s Pete Townshend on Rock’s Legacy, and His Own Dark Past

docs.abstract: It is easy to ignore climate change in the bosom of the developed world. But you can’t fail to notice when the lights go out.
docs.snippet: It is easy to ignore climate change in the bosom of the developed world. But you can’t fail to notice when the lights go out.
docs.lead_paragraph: At the beginning of October, my kids’ preschool informed me that it might be closed the next day because of rolling blackouts — a radical new effort by our local power utility in Northern California to avoid sparking wildfires. The water company, faced with the shutdown of its pumps, asked us to fill our bathtubs before the cutoff. On the advice of experts, my car was backed into the driveway for a quick escape, its hatch packed with seven gallons of water and a go-bag including leather gloves, breathing masks, spare clothes, headlamps and emergency food.

docs.abstract: Watch a conversation about how history is defined — and redefined — featuring historians, journalists and policymakers.
docs.snippet: Watch a conversation about how history is defined — and redefined — featuring historians, journalists and policymakers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Four hundred years ago, a ship carrying 20 to 30 enslaved Africans arrived at Point Comfort in the English colony of Virginia. Though the United States did not even exist yet, their arrival marked its foundation, the beginning of the system of slavery on which the country was built.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Museum of African American History and Culture

docs.abstract: Should you put your feet inside?
docs.snippet: Should you put your feet inside?
docs.lead_paragraph: Sol writes: When taking a bath, my 4-year-old son, Dylan, insists that I put my feet in the tub by the drain to protect him from sharks. I’ve tried to explain that a shark will probably not come up through the drain, and that if one did manage to do so and grab my feet, I would instinctively grab onto him, and we would both be dragged into death’s maw. His position hasn’t changed. Do I have to do it?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Sharks in the Tub
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Is it O.K. to read about the ending on Wikipedia?
docs.snippet: Is it O.K. to read about the ending on Wikipedia?
docs.lead_paragraph: Jayson writes: In my family, we watch a new movie every Friday night. However, my mother always brings out her phone halfway through and reads the ending on Wikipedia. This is not fair for two reasons: I do not have a phone, and it is an insult to the filmmakers and actors.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Movie-Night Spoilers
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: How lazy is a would-be streamer allowed to be?
docs.snippet: How lazy is a would-be streamer allowed to be?
docs.lead_paragraph: Jeremy writes: A friend of mine, Sigh, has been trying to become a video-game streamer for a while. Recently he was invited to become a “partner,” meaning he can start making money off his channel. He just needs to file some simple paperwork. It has been a month, and he still hasn’t done it. I would like you to order him to file the paperwork.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Professional Gamers
headline.kicker: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Do they deserve a spot? Even if they only want an invite so they can reject it?
docs.snippet: Do they deserve a spot? Even if they only want an invite so they can reject it?
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael writes: I dated a friend of mine briefly years back, and we keep in touch via social media. She is getting married and didn’t invite me. She thinks it would be strange for an ex to be at a wedding, especially because I don’t have relationships with anyone else attending. Please rule that she invite me so I have the chance to decline.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Inviting Exes to Weddings
headline.kicker: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Should men be expected to put the seat back down when they’re done?
docs.snippet: Should men be expected to put the seat back down when they’re done?
docs.lead_paragraph: Evangeline writes: I currently live with my boyfriend, Nate. We have had an ongoing argument about the toilet seat. He believes that he should not put the seat down after he uses the toilet. I, on the other hand, believe it is the man’s responsibility to put the toilet seat down after he uses it. To this day, we still cannot agree as to who is right and who is wrong. He still leaves the seat up, and it still drives me nuts. Please help!

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on the Famous Toilet Seat Debate
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Can you give sweets you found in the garbage to your co-workers without telling them where they came from?
docs.snippet: Can you give sweets you found in the garbage to your co-workers without telling them where they came from?
docs.lead_paragraph: Meridith writes: My friend obtained a significant quantity of chocolate from a dumpster outside a beloved local chocolate factory. He then shared it with his co-workers without disclosing the source. I believe he should have let his co-workers know that the chocolate came from a dumpster. He contends that he did nothing wrong. Who’s right?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Gifting Dumpster Chocolate
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.lead_paragraph: Arielle writes: My office hosts a casual baking contest. We vote for a winner by writing on Post-its and putting them in a cup. Now my friend wants people to fill out scorecards from “The Great British Bake Off,” with categories for presentation, creativity and flavour with a “u.” I think she really wants to extend the criteria because she would always win for presentation.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Office Baking Contests
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman
